content:
Posted: March 1, 2014
												I don't normally play exploration games.  Kairo is probably the closest thing to immersion that I wanted from a puzzle/exploration game besides the Myst series.  The music is the most immersive aspect of Kairo. It will bring you into this world.  It should be noted that there is no spoken dialogue or text to read. You start off in this world and have to figure out where to go and what to do. The puzzles aren't terribly difficult. The hardest one for me so far only took 20 minutes to solve.  I'm still playing this pretty awesome game for 5 bucks but I can already say it's worth a buy!

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 29, 2014
												When I saw the screenshots and such for Kairo I presumed that Kairo may not be the most visually appealing game but sometimes, while such games may not always put their best screenshots on display, they do usually have some redeeming charm. The various positive reviews and an endorsement from RPS also seemed to indicate that this was a diamond in the rough. However as it turned out, it is actually a mouldy chunk of food in the dust. How on earth this game achieved anywhere near a positive status on Steam I have no idea, but I suspect foul play. Allow me to explain why you need to avoid Kairo like the plague.Plain textures can sometimes be compensated for by some impressively detailed architecture or environments which hold intrigue. Kairo simply does not have any of that. The environments look like they were made by someone experimenting with mapping and decided to package everything together to make it seem like a game. The designer has some strange idea that throwing tons of fog into every section of the game is a substitute for creating atmospheric lighting or using the environment itself to influence the players' state of mind. As such every part of the game I saw felt lifeless, unfinished and bland. I have honestly seen maps from the original Quake with more atmosphere, style and imagination.The 'puzzles' are so dull that I literally gave up after playing the game for half an hour. They consist of running into invisible triggers or standing on trigger brushes to cause something to happen. One of the things the designer forgot to actually do is clearly indicate when a puzzle is solved and what the point of solving it was. In one area I found 4 platforms which turned on a bunch of particle effects on a rotating central disc. Visually quite interesting and clearly the puzzle was solved because all of the triggers stopped working, but it did not appear to have any effect upon the game. The lack of direction here is astounding as the designer chooses to leave you completely in the dark as to what you should be doing and gives no context or sense of progress to what you manage to figure out on your own. Someone needs to sit this person down with games like Myst, the Longest Journey, Master Reboot or even The Room so they can understand the difference between an enjoyable mystery and aimless activity.Kairo is unpleasant to look at, boring to explore, devoid of any sense of achievement or purpose and ultimately one of the worst games I have had the misfortune to mistake for a worthwhile investment of money or time.

content:
Posted: November 29, 2014
												When I saw the screenshots and such for Kairo I presumed that Kairo may not be the most visually appealing game but sometimes, while such games may not always put their best screenshots on display, they do usually have some redeeming charm. The various positive reviews and an endorsement from RPS also seemed to indicate that this was a diamond in the rough. However as it turned out, it is actually a mouldy chunk of food in the dust. How on earth this game achieved anywhere near a positive status on Steam I have no idea, but I suspect foul play. Allow me to explain why you need to avoid Kairo like the plague.Plain textures can sometimes be compensated for by some impressively detailed architecture or environments which hold intrigue. Kairo simply does not have any of that. The environments look like they were made by someone experimenting with mapping and decided to package everything together to make it seem like a game. The designer has some strange idea that throwing tons of fog into every section of the game is a substitute for creating atmospheric lighting or using the environment itself to influence the players' state of mind. As such every part of the game I saw felt lifeless, unfinished and bland. I have honestly seen maps from the original Quake with more atmosphere, style and imagination.The 'puzzles' are so dull that I literally gave up after playing the game for half an hour. They consist of running into invisible triggers or standing on trigger brushes to cause something to happen. One of the things the designer forgot to actually do is clearly indicate when a puzzle is solved and what the point of solving it was. In one area I found 4 platforms which turned on a bunch of particle effects on a rotating central disc. Visually quite interesting and clearly the puzzle was solved because all of the triggers stopped working, but it did not appear to have any effect upon the game. The lack of direction here is astounding as the designer chooses to leave you completely in the dark as to what you should be doing and gives no context or sense of progress to what you manage to figure out on your own. Someone needs to sit this person down with games like Myst, the Longest Journey, Master Reboot or even The Room so they can understand the difference between an enjoyable mystery and aimless activity.Kairo is unpleasant to look at, boring to explore, devoid of any sense of achievement or purpose and ultimately one of the worst games I have had the misfortune to mistake for a worthwhile investment of money or time.

content:
Posted: April 2
												First room teaches you that you can fly (or rather, walk) over bottomless pits.  Then you get hit with invisible walls so you can't fall.  Then you fall.  Lesson learned: mechanics are meant to confuse you.Level design looks like someone found the "cube" tool and said "this is everything I need".   Most rooms use symmetric architecture to disorient you.  Room are connected by portal-doors with unmemorable splashes of color to distinguish them (e.g. red portal vs. blue portal).  Lesson learned: basic navigation is meant to confuse you.Puzzles are trivially easy, when they work at all.  There is no "use" button and so everything is activated by stepping on a specific piece of floor or pushing against a particular wall.  Anything more complex, such as pushing a handle on a rotating cylinder, is just as likely to not work as it is to work slowly.  Some rooms have no puzzle at all but things that you interact with like other puzzles.  Lesson learned: puzzle elements are meant to confuse you.Normally I'd think such a consistent design of confusion was serving a larger theme.  It's not.  It's just a bad game.

												I honesly have no idea how this game is 75% positive reviews. Kairo is supposed to be a 3D exploration puzzler, but it fails to do both. The puzzles that I had to solve during my short 30 minutes of playtime were not enjoyable in the slightest. Most of them were completely mundane. I didn't feel like I accomplished anything when I solved the puzzles. The "exploration" aspect is also done poorly. With poor platforming controls and the ability to see through walls at 90 FOV, the game is already to a poor start. Add on to this a bleak world with no interesting things to interact with or even LOOK at, and I found myself just going from corridor to corridor so I could finish this damn game as quick as possible.Pros:-Runs smoothlyCons:-Boring puzzles-Bad graphics-Poor platforming controls

												It tries to be Myst.and it isn't; the premise of this game is to open possible and ambiguity of story for intrepretation by the players, narration is being pushed to extreme minimum and almost non-existence, relying in "dumb dog puzzles" as the core mechanic of this game. the devs tries to be as minimalist as possible and resulting in being incredibly slow and boring, even when you do (and could) running in-game. the art design seems to unsure whether it want's to be in voxel or high res textured, even though there's almost nothing to show due to heavy emphasis on surreal atmospheric term (in this case, its kinda work... sort of).It could be great, short game but somehow ended up being stretch beyond what is necessary. what could be 30 minutes game with more replayability and more variety of ending turns up as overly long walking simulator with very little redeeming value of gameplay and non-rewarding short ending (and that "ending") gets a barely thumbs down. good discount will help decided people to buy this game though.(5.4/10) could be better.

content:
Posted: July 18, 2015
												If you have ever went on a walk, in an empty gymnasium with your eyes closed, you probably would find Kairo boring in comparison. In Kairo you get to do a lot of walking. I think. Actually I have no idea what this game actually IS.... When I am playing it, I feel as though I'm stuck in Half Life's tram car, able to look around, move a little, but nothing actually happens.Actually that's a bit generous. It's more like waiting for your girlfriend to come downstairs for your date - you can walk around, check out the books on her book shelf, look at the dirt on the floor... all with an anticipation that she would be coming down stairs ANY minute,., She never does - and THAT's Kairo's entire gameplay model.Did I like it? I can't say, I never actually DID anything. Oh sure, doors opened, things clicked, but unless I'm missing the point, the entire purpose of this game is to show how nicely you can make big ugly square blocks look sometimes.I'd like to see what the developer actually intended, some day.

content:
Posted: December 4, 2015
												What am I even doing?Kairo is a very beautiful and ambient puzzle game with zero help and is the complete opposite of linear. It had puzzles and walking parts that have no connection and will leave you completely lost 95% of the way, some people may like that but it was a massive turn off for me. I used a guide for most of the game just so I could get it finished and write this review. My girlfriend tried it so I could make sure it wasent just me not knowing what I was doing, shes very puzzle smart and gets these kinda things really easily, but she became frustrated at the lack of help you are given. Most of the puzzles have no logical conclusion and will just make you guess forever until you figure it with just blind luck and perserverence.What it does right is make a story and really get the feeling of mystery and uncertainty embeded into the entire experience.With a guide it took me 3.5 hours to complete, without I would say if you didn't go insane already and forgot what time even is it will take 10+I really wanted to recommend this game, I bought it on sale thinking it was going to be this amazing ambient adventure with clear colours and pretty shapes but I really can't, it just makes no sense.It had promise and if it had just a little help to give you it would of been three times the game it is, but all I experienced was a mess of beautiful art.Personal Rating: 2/5

content:
Posted: November 27, 2015
												I didn't like Kairo. It feels unfinished. And the blinding white sky and strange visual appearance kind of give me a headache. The game doesn't teach well at all, so you feel unsure of what you should be doing. It is not nearly linear enough, and has no sense of accomplishment. I purchased it because it looked so promising, but the game fails to deliver. I hate to write a negative review, but this game is just not well put together or polished. The levels don't have a consistent feel or visual style, the architecture is not believable, navigation is difficult and the player just needs a LOT more direction.If the game was linear, taught skills incrementally, was more intuitive, rewarded the player, had save points, and was easier to navigate it could be a really fun game. But it doesn't quite do what a game should. It has a lot of potential, though, and it is too bad that it isn't more finished.

content:
Posted: June 8, 2016
I dont think this qualifies as a game.It is more like tech demo for an old and bad engine.When you boot the game up,you are greeted with SPECTACULAR controls.Whoever made this game thought it was a good idea to apply smoothing to CONTROLS.And thank god i realized that you can turn it off at least for mouse.You had one job as a walking simulator:BEING ABLE TO WALK.This must be someones first game or something,and it is good AS SOMEONE'S FIRST GAME,but its pretty sh*t as a real game.Then we got the textures and oh boy,arent they sh*t.Textures 101:DO NOT CREATE A WALL WİTH ONLY THE SAME TEXTURE.HAVE VARIATION.Also polygons.You need 'em.And we get to the "story":This is why i called this game a tech demo rather than a game.If you remove every text from a game,there will be NO ROOM FOR STORY.Oh and puzzles arent great.And you are trying to be "atmospheric" ,huh?-No graphics-No controls-No story.How were you planning to be atmospheric again?At least have one of them.P.S. Remove the cheap grain effect before saying i was wrong about the graphics.That effect is the cheapest trick i have ever seen so far.And there it is,after being thru at least 50 of this type,the first time i actually used "I Do not recommend "button.TL;DR :-Worst controls.-Motion sickness.-GldSrc engine level graphics.-♥♥♥♥♥ier textures.+Decent music.Down it with beer.3/10 : A badly made half-life mod.(With fitting music tho.)

Posted: June 29, 2014
												Kairo is a very peculiar indie game with interesting puzzles that focus on visual cues (next to nothing audibly). If you have a decent computer and own FRAPS, then you should have no problem (REQUIRES FRAMELOCK), but for those of you who do not, I would be weary. My setup was running Kairo at 300+ FPS and quickly became dizzy and nauseated which lasted longer than it should have. Requiring a framelocking software in order to experience the game as it was meant to be is a turn off. Not to mention most won't know what framelocking is or how to do it.

content:
Posted: July 1, 2016
												Usually I like this kind of game, and usually I don't write reviews for games I don't like. But this game is unusually disappointing.Maybe I'd enjoy it if it were properly playable, but it isn't. Huge input lag even when the framerate is high and smooth. Walking controls are really slippery, too. It doesn't look very good and yet manages to run poorly anyway. If you stray from the expected path, the game may not understand and may just throw you into a death loop. (Try jumping on the radio obelisk. You'll see.)I only managed to get through a few areas. The terrible input lag was just too distracting to tolerate in this kind of game, where imersion is important.

number of helpful: 0 of 3 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 1, 2016
												Quit on I don't even know which puzzle.  The "puzzles" aren't well designed; much of the time you stumble around till you happen to find something that goes *ding*.They aren't really original either; press these things in the right order (not even halfway through the game, I ran into a few of those), push this thing around, move to some particular, non-indicated location (that showed up about 5 times so far in the second "world")They're also slow.  Like, press a certain 2 buttons in a giant room.  Or push 4 boxes around a huge room while you wait for  a ball to bounce around like a snail.  Or wait on a button while a slow cube spins 360.  Or walk 3 flights of stairs in a room without any puzzle at all.  Or just walk on *nothing* to some non-descript platform in the distance.They're also poorly constructed.  Don't make the geometry such that I can get caught in a place I'm only supposed to push a ball.  Don't throw random barriers and little pathways that look traversible but lead to nothing (or maybe lead to a tiny rune thing which disappears before you even know what you did)ugh.  Other reviews are praising this for its ambience, for its minimalist "elegance", whatever.  And that's what convinced me to buy this.  But I got little to no enjoyment from what I played; I was expecting a much more fleshed-out game (which doesn't contradict minimalism; take Anti-chamber, for example)

content:
Posted: January 27
												Great atmosphere, made me want to explore and see what's next. But I can't recomend this game, as a puzzle game is terrible. The puzzle designs are even insulting at some times. Believe me, if you want to play this game you will have to use a walktrough guide because there will be puzzles that are literally impossible, and not because you are not smart enough, but because they are designed to actually be impossible. Yes, it is stupid to make a game that way, and yes, Kairo is uber stupid game design.Just to give you an example (one of many situations like this in the game, and there are a lot, believe me): There is a room where you see this kind of hexagonal button, you get close to it, you touch it and a it glows and what appears to be some tv screens arround the room are now turned on with some noisy image. You think to your self "that's it?, that's what this button did?" There seems to be that nothing else have changed in that room after all. Well, guess what? There is a f*cking door that was hidden in some other room that you already been through about one hour ago, and that door is now open, and you have to go back to that random place, with out any clue whatsoever so you enter this new room to do something else, that is actually required for some other sh*t further in the game! How am I supposed to know that I have to go to that f*cking place? And that's why you must use a f*cking walkthrough! But a game that requires that in the first place so that you are able to play it is a bloody f*cking stupid game!!!

I guess people are too involved in the creator's personal life or something. I have no idea. I'm not rating personal drama here. I'm rating the game. And there isn't much here beyond a bare bones approach to the puzzle genre. I still recommend it for super cheap, but just barely compared to the rest of the puzzle genre.Some of the puzzles are fun, some of the music has a nice ambient tone, and I guess the graphics are okay. But there isn't much here. This is archaic modeling, basic sound loops, and not much else to be quite honest. I mean, I can see why people appreciate indies, I'm just not sure why this game is worth my time. I come back to it and do a bit of a puzzle I guess because the game is in my library. But I'm not sure I will ever complete this game, and I don't really care.I find the the extras to be tepid, and some of the puzzles are illogical or just downright irritating. This is not Myst, Obduction, Antichamber, or Talos, so don't even start to compare it to those masterpieces. It has nothing on them. This game is like a game some programmer set up in 1999 as a project to test out a graphic engine. It's okay.But I really cannot 100% recommend stuff like this when there is so much more out there. It's one of those games, because it has a decent tone to it, that I will give a 5.5/10. The reviews are so overwhelmingly positive that Kairo needs a couple more negative interpretations because it doesn't really do anything special to earn those positive reviews. So yes play it and try the game out. But I am giving a thumbs down because this is clearly just a shell of a real, immersive experience.

The atmosphere is great and a lot of the areas (Especially the famous "red pylon" room) are fantastic looking, but...The puzzles feel bland and useless, like they were taked on to give the game uneeded "difficulty" (of which there is none even with puzzles), the music can be grating at times, and some of the stuff, like the static, screens, or door effects, feel a bit out of place.I can definitely respect what the game was trying to do, and in terms of being a "wow look at this giant otherworldly thing" game it succeeds, but i think that adding ridiculously easy puzzles and the sort actually took away from the game rather than added to it. content:
Posted: December 15, 2014
												I don't think I've ever regretted spending $5.I put a little under an hour and a half into this game before I made the decision to uninstall it.Here is my reasoning.I bought the game because some reviewers touted its similarity to Antichamber, a game that is very near and dear to my heart. The trailer for the game made it appear tantalizing and intriguing and, most of all, fun. Unfortunately, it didn't take me twenty minutes to regret this small purchase.Kairo has, I've found, missed the mark on one of the most fundamental gaming concepts; not just in video games, but in the entire realm of playing a game for fun. I call this "carrot-and-stick". Other people call this other things. But essentially, in nearly every game you can think of, there's the metaphorical carrot, your objective, and the metaphorical stick, what keeps you from your objective. I could cite endless games, card games, board games, arcade games, games of make-believe played in the backyard of my friends' houses when we were five, and, yes, video games that keep/kept me latched onto the idea, entertained, and engaged in the gameplay.One thing I quickly learned in Kairo is that there's not much of a carrot.I'm going to take this discussion back to Antichamber, for those who have played it. I'd hypothesize that the two are compared often for the similar concept of working through puzzles in complete solitude. But in the Hub of Antichamber, you can see a door marked Exit, though you cannot reach it. In one of the first spawn points, you can see a door behind a barrier marked "The End". There's even the Black Ghost, dancing just out of your reach on certain puzzles. These are all suitable carrots. Kairo is designed in such a way that I have yet to see the carrot; there's not much more than an endless stick. And after almost an hour and a half of playing for no apparent reason, I tired of the game.On one last note, for all the endless puzzles in Kairo, there are worlds you walk through that have no puzzles at all. The game has a hint feature, but if you are not so inclined to use it, it's incredibly difficult to discern a puzzle world from a world that's apparently there for your exhaustive visual pleasure.

number of helpful: 2 of 9 people (22%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
												Before I begin, I have played for more than 0.3 hours, but I played in offline mod. Not very much though, this game made me bored faster than a math lesson can do.Positives:- Decent scripting I guessNegatives:- Pretty much everything- Boring gameplay- No storylineYou spawn in a world with absoutely no clue how you got there. You don't have a name, you don't have a goal, you don't have anything to find. The story is non existing.Some games can be good even without a clear goal or a background story, but not in this case.Not only do you have no goal, enemies or purpose in Kairo whatsoever, the puzzles are also simple but yet confusing. You can not interact with anything and you don't have an inventory, meaning that all you can do is move objects by walking towards them, or jump on random platforms in hope that something will happen. Really, really simple puzzles. And when I say it's also confusing, what I mean is, you don't really know why you are doing what you are doing due to the non existing story and the few hints you get doesn't really help that much at all.Do I recommend this game? No. I don't recommend it to anyone.People that love adventures, no. The game is as simple as it can be (including the soundtracks and gameplay in general) with nothing to explore or discover at all. You don't even have a purpose or anything to lose. Not even health (no, you can't even die in this game).People that like puzzle games, no. Again, the puzzles are basic, yet confusing, and you don't really know why you are doing them.People that love a good storyline, no. There is no story in this game at all.-------------------Why people like this is beyond me. I have played many bad games, but this without doubt in my top 5 most boring games ever.2/10 - Really bad

content:
Posted: November 10, 2014
												As someone who used to work with mapping for garry's mod I can clearly see that the mapping in this game is terrible. Another problem is that the controls are inexplicably sluggish and you feel as if you're on ice skates while you walk. I thought it might be because of my computer but the framerate is very good and there is no mouse lag so the problem has to be related to the game. Now, I understand that this game is inspired by yume nikki, but that is no excuse to make the puzzles so obscure without a hint on how to solve them. yume nikki itself was not a finished game you know. All in all, I want to get immersed into the game but the lack of polish and sluggish controls make it impossible to do so.Until this game is properly polished I can't recommend it.If the dev wants help with mapping, I would be willing to help if I can, for a small fee of course.

content:
Posted: December 5, 2016
Kairo has managed to annoy me, that is why the negative vote. Apart from that, the game possesses couple of merits worth to be pointed out. Despite being designed in a simplistic manner, it offers beautiful vistas. The music accompanying the course of play is remarkable on its own, creating a decent atmosphere. Unfortunately, when it comes to contents, the puzzles are either straightforward or frustratingly hard, including some obsolete-minded solutions, such as dragging the face along the walls throughout several impressively large areas, just to find that little secret. To summarise, if you seek loose Portal-meets-Tomb-Raider-type atmospheric exploration available at low cost, get Kairo. If you want intellectually challenging journey in the vein of Antichamber, move on.

												Kairo is a first person puzzle-game that made me go "Where the heck am I supposed to go?"It's a cryptic game, really is. There are secrets runes hidden all over the game along the road of its many puzzles.There is no way to die in the game besides falling off, but you don't really die - it just sends you back from where you fell.It's a lonely experience with its ambience and ..if you can even call it music.There are weird things happening here and there......but the game has the best coffee ad you'll ever see.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 21, 2014
												This game is pretty crazy. Somewhere between fascinating and terrifying, wondrous and foreboding. There are no monsters or even imminent threats really, but still your entire surroundings feel so ancient and so much grander than you that it creates an incredibly ominous feeling that never quite goes away.As you interact with the world, huge abandoned structures come to life, and though the scenery changes and the paths are made clear, you never really know what’s going on under the surface. What do these huge contraptions actually do? Where is it leading? And how did all of it (and you for that matter) end up here? You get the sense that you’ll never really know, because it’s all just too ancient, too alien for your understanding.The entire experience is rather chilling, and if you let yourself really become immersed in this world, you’ll probably find yourself making some pretty strange sounds, like I was, and laughing at points about just how uncomfortable it actually makes you.The game isn’t perfect. There are bugs, but those tend to add to the strangeness of the environment in a way. One noticeable fault I had was that the footstep sounds are the exact same no matter what your pace is. This may sound minor, but it is rather noticeable at times when you are really taking it slow to take in your surroundings, which you will probably do quite a lot. Still a minor complaint in face of everything that’s really on display in this one.I bought it during a Summer Sale at $1.50, and I would probably recommend it at a fairly higher price-tag even still.MY SCORE - 8/10

content:
Posted: August 15, 2013
												Kairo is a great little game with really nice logic puzzles that aren't too difficult but requires some thinking. The game hints at a story but it's very vague and it could just as well have no story. The thing I really loved about Kairo was the atmosphere it created, it made me feel very isolated and small because the levels were usually very big and empty and it had a very minimalist environment. The atmosphere got creepy at times as things such as static on the screen would flare up and number station recordings would play as you got closer to certain areas. The game always had me questioning things, because sometimes strange objects or symbols would be around and it would make me want to know why they were there or what they meant. I also liked the ambient music as that too helped with the atmosphere and it fits right into the game.

												An extremely underrated game -- period. This game boasts a power to enthrall and captivate you, without needing an actual story the game almost speaks to you on a mystical level. The puzzles aren't easy but not too difficult, and there are very creative ideas put into it. The game also has intresting architecture and mysterious entities. content:
Posted: March 6, 2014
												     From the moment the game begins to the ending sequence, Kairo's atmosphere remains powerful and unique. The world feels vast and lonely, but far from empty. The world is strange and yet eerily familiar, and the puzzles keep you involved in the goal. You can spend hours exploring the numerous rooms, each with its own atmosphere and function.     Very simple controls stop you from playing the guessing game on how to interact with things, so that the focus can be on the environment and puzzles that surround you. The music and atmospheric sounds add to the vast and lonely feeling of the world, and some elements you come across can send shivers down your spine.     If you're one for getting lost in an atmosphere, this is a game for you.

												Brilliant. Completely dedicated to abstraction from beginning to end. No text, no tutorial, no explanations, no HUD. No traditional narrative or plot, only dream logic, mood and an amazingly realized sense of scale and place. The puzzles are often simple and follow an intuitive sort of logic (with a few unfortunate exceptions). Kairo is eerie, beautiful, mysterious, always unpredictable and intriguing. It's very much what I had hoped Antichamber would be.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 24, 2014
												Need a break?Welcome to the strange, yet simple and relaxing world of Kairo. It's a world filled with many ambiances, many puzzles, and many secrets.The gameplay is that simple, reduced to only movements, triggers activating by just pushing or walking passed them. Most of the puzzles also aren't difficult, with hints provided in the menu if you need some help. Though, some secrets are pretty hard to find or solve, and you might want to pass them if you don't want to spend a lot of time on them.But what makes Kairo different is the collection of ambiances and places, some people might see them like poetry, despite the lack of plot. Of course you will have a hard time enjoying this if you seek action.Overall, its a nice, short, but most importantly relaxing game.Be careful though, despite the quite simple graphics, it seems the game needs quite the resource, and you don't have many graphic options to help it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 25, 2014
												Kairo just seems like it was made for VR. The best way to describe is it is a Myst like experience where you travel through enormous rooms and areas that are large puzzles to figure out. There's no weaponry, no enemies unless you count the puzzles and you pretty much cannot die (falling off ledges just puts you back on the ledge). Each room is dominated by a simple color scheme and the architecture is large and blocky as giving the environment an ancient feel.When played on a normal monitor, the simple graphics and plain architecture might seem like a negative. However, you activate VR, put on the Rift and you realize these graphics are now a strength. Just as Valve Steam Dev Days demo showed, so long as you keep latency low and frame rate high even a simple environment will seem real. Kairo delivers on this concept in spades. The large throne rooms, invisible maze arena, hollow pyramids, giant light orb and many other breathtaking sites fill this game. The slow pace and not too mind bending puzzles mean you're seeing new areas yet have plenty of time to appreciate each one. The sounds are different for each location and all are relaxing and never seem to be over bearing or painfully loud. There are a few cases where the sudden movement of the environment surprised me, but never did I feel the need to pull out of the game. The presence is strong and even with lengthy gameplay I did not notice much if any in the way of nausea. The frame rate seems great throughout with only one room (the one with four treadmills) showing lag.Like Dear Esther, I play this game standing up and do the fake foot walk to aid in my immersion. The look is not tied to the control movement so it's easy to look around and enjoy the environment as you travel through. Its very easy to get drawn into the game and forget that you're in your room playing a game.People probably have missed that this is a VR game as it does not seem to have the "VR Support" tag in the Steam search function. I've written the author and asked if he can get that added. As I said, for only $5 you're getting several hours of a great VR experience. A perfect game for those that prefer relaxed gameplay over the horror or shooter style games currently listed with VR support.

content:
Posted: August 15, 2013
												Kairo is a great little game with really nice logic puzzles that aren't too difficult but requires some thinking. The game hints at a story but it's very vague and it could just as well have no story. The thing I really loved about Kairo was the atmosphere it created, it made me feel very isolated and small because the levels were usually very big and empty and it had a very minimalist environment. The atmosphere got creepy at times as things such as static on the screen would flare up and number station recordings would play as you got closer to certain areas. The game always had me questioning things, because sometimes strange objects or symbols would be around and it would make me want to know why they were there or what they meant. I also liked the ambient music as that too helped with the atmosphere and it fits right into the game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 29, 2015
												I got this game for $1. And I'm glad I scooped it up! A great puzzle/exploration game with enigmas abound.GAMEPLAY: Consists of walking, jumping, and looking around. It's straightforward exploration with minor platforming. Puzzles round out the play, which you complete by stepping on platforms and bumping into objects to trigger them.PUZZLES: They're pretty intuitive for the most part, but there were a few I had to consult the helpfully provided "hints" option for (one in particular was hair rippingly frustrating because I'm terrible at math). Be prepared to comb areas carefully for clues, and draw out some diagrams here and there. It's quite satisfying to solve these puzzles, as they're fairly challenging, and it's made clear when you have activated a piece of machinery or opened a pathway by way of flashing lights, thunderous tumults, or loud gong strikes. It all amounts to a feeling of progress and getting one step closer to solving the mystery.VISUALS: Very minimalistic. Oftentimes, you wander through barren corridors or empty voids, with sparsely a decoration to look at. What there is to look at, though, serves to deepen the mystery. It feels like everything being presented - from images of Earth to the DNA double helix - has some type of underlying meaning. Otherwise, lighting and colouring is used to differentiate rooms, creating a very surreal effect. There's also some use of moving objects - floating, spinning globes, for example - that add some variance. In all, it's simplistic, but only where it needs to be.AUDIO: The highlight of the game for me. Again, simplicity is the standard here - a haunting, ambient soundtrack makes the place feel mysterious, dangerous, and cozy all at once. It's a strange effect, but it keeps the player guessing as to what, exactly, these structures are. As mentioned before, loud, sudden bells and gongs are used to indicate that the player has completed a puzzle, which is pretty satisfying. Radio static in certain locations and chimes during object interaction round out the auditory experience. Like the graphics, it feels like the sounds of the game highlight what's important.STORY: Ostensibly, there isn't much of one. There is virtually no dialogue or cutscenes, and there are no NPCs present. Only environmental clues, mainly through recurring motifs, give rise to some semblance of a plot. I enjoyed wondering what Kairo could be about, and reading theories about it afterward.Overall, a great experience, which is even nicer considering I got this game for $1. It reminded me a lot of Myst (and Penumbra, somehow). There are mysteries to be unravelled for those willing to search for them.

content:
Posted: September 6, 2015
												I quite enjoyed this game. The atmosphere was great, and it looked really cool. However, some of the puzzles were a bit -too- abstract, and for some reason touching a wall caused my framerate to drop dramatically. This got annoying in some areas, espeically being that the controls in this game aren't very tight, even with the settings tweaked. Some areas a a bit bigger than they need to be, so there's a lot of walking to do. Thank goodness there's a sprint button, but it doesn't change your speed that much. This game has very little replay value, unless you're one of those people who want to painstakingly go through every nook and cranny to find these tiny symbols tucked in corners of the levels.I think the game was trying to tell me a story, but I didn't get any sort of feeling of resolution at the end, unless I am supposed to find all those little symbols. That sounds absolutely miserable though. That would be like playing a 3d eye spy game. I have better things to do with my life.Overall, I enjoyed the game. Puzzles were nice, except for a few, which were really stupidly hard. The game is not that long at all, so these few dark spots really put a dent in the overall experience.I almost gave this a thumbs down, but at the end of the day, it did hold my attention, and I did say twice in this review that I enjoyed it, so it gets a thumbs up from me. But just barely.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 18, 2015
												Okay, let's get one thing out of the way first: this game does not look good. The trailer above kinda oversells the graphics — they're not minimalistic, they're cheap.That being said, everything else about Kairo is great.Distant cousin of Myst, this game is comprised mostly of puzzles. And there is a compelling diversity in these: some are very easy, some are very difficult; some totally straightforward, some mind-bendingly abstract; and of course everything in between. This makes the progression always enticing and never boring. The level design is very cool despite the poor graphics and each level has its own unique feel, the whole game being very "atmospheric". This is brilliantly reinforced by the marvelous sound design, with a really, really awesome music that transported me from puzzle to puzzle in a dream-like state.Thanks to all these strenghts, Kairo manages to be at the same time fun and relaxing. It is a journey, really, in a land full of mysteries and secrets, where lots of questions are raised and no explanations given — you make your own conclusions from the scarce clues given along the path.I have no idea how to grade it out of ten, but I am positive that I'd recommend it in a heartbeat to pretty much anyone. The only major flaw that I would point out is the absence of V-Sync which allows some MASSIVE tearing to occur. And the Field of View is rendered in layers, which looks kinda awful. But other than that, well... What's not to like? You like puzzles? Get it. Like "moody" games? It's a good one. Like quality OSTs? This one's perfect. You like Myst? Don't hesitate! There even is a skeleton hidden somewhere. Spooky!

												A short but interesting puzzle and exploration game. The puzzles are mostly intuitive, and there's a hint series for each room if you get stuck, which I greatly appreciated. The graphics are simple blocky 3D, but the art style is fascinating, with huge elaborate temple complexes and imposing architecture. number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 22, 2015
												Kairo is a slow-paced puzzle game in a similar vein to Myst, if Myst didn't have all the annoying pixel-hunting and weren't a point and click game. Its atmosphere is surreal, strange, and overwhelmingly lonesome. That's the big word I think I'd use to describe this game - lonesome, and that lonesomeness becomes more and more eerie the further you go into the game. You are the only living thing in Kairo - everything else is a hollow, dead fascimile, with archetecture eerily reminiscent of human construction and yet alien enough you might think you woke up in R'lyeh. The world of Kairo is a small world that feels massive, alien, and completely dead... and I love it to pieces and back.Wandering through the surreal and beautifully eerie world of Kairo is very relaxing, the puzzles are very intuitive and can easily be solved with a little thought, and the simple design really makes it feel like you're stranded. And yet, solving the puzzles is so satisfying, satisfying in that "I'm a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ed genius!" sort of way. The range of feelings you get from Kairo goes from triumph, curiosity, and awe to fright, paranoia, and hopelessness - and what is art if not something that makes you feel deeply? Anyone who claims video games aren't art has never played this, and that's a damn shame. Did I mention that the music and the game's design is just so surrealistically gorgeous?Seriously, BUY THIS GAME. It's maybe $5 for a wonderful little piece of surrealistic artwork that recaptures the eerie loneliness and thirst for adventure that Myst did so many years ago in 1992. Kairo is a gem of an indie puzzle game, and anyone who is a fan of surreal artwork, puzzle games, and games where you chill and wander for a bit will love this. You really do owe it to yourself to play it at least once. Who knows? It may become one of your favorite games, just like it has for me.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 13, 2015
												NOTE: For review with screenshots, please visit http://microfloppy.net/2015/06/14/kairo/Kairo is a puzzle exploration game. You travel the world of Kairo, trying to move forward and get to the next door… and the next… and the next.The graphics are simple – smooth and coloured walls will keep you company. It gives the game a cold and sinister feel. I felt small and lost, running around in large buildings, trying to get out.You have no inventory, no set of tools to help you out. Instead you unlock your surroundings by how and where you move and what you do. It’s a very unnerving and immersive experience.It is difficult to explain this game without saying too much. But playing Kairo, I felt like I was the last person in the world, trying desperately to find my way out of a complex I was not meant to be in. If you like first-person explorations games, you should play this one.7/10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 5, 2015
												IMPORTANT: When you hit the normal ending, wait for the credits to play out. They're not long.Pros:- Puzzles become interesting when you have no "hand" or "activate" controls. By limiting the player to mere movement controls, old puzzles feel fresh, and there's an extra sense of accomplishment with even fairly simple puzzles.- The environment's minimalist polygon theme manages, surprisingly, to stay varied, interesting, and even evokative throughout the game, contributing to the theme of "strange and yet familiar" that pervades.- Difficulty to normal end is low, difficulty to secret end is high.- No penalty for exploration, experimentation, or taking your time.- Overall, definitely enjoyable.Cons:- The "story" aspect is a little too vague. You paid $5, folks, this ain't Myst or Portal. While there are enough "clues" that a player can vaguely put together a plot (and considerably more blatant clues as rewards for solving secret puzzles), there's plenty that's just left to imagination.- The mechanic that resets you to a safe ledge can glitch considerably, leaving you in a fall-to-your-death loop, though this can be solved by exiting the game and reloading.- One of the final secret puzzles is actually impossible to solve on your own. Your game will have 1/5 of the solution, and which fifth is chosen at random. So you're either going to need lots of friends, or cheat and look at a walkthrough.Final Note: Don't take my playtime as a good guide to the runthrough time of this game. I got irritated and consulted a walkthrough for two of the secret puzzles and half the rune locations.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 27, 2016
												Kairo is a slightly flawed gem of a first-person walking and exploration game. It requires a bit of investment to stay interested in the beginning, but if you're into discovery and piecing together parts of a mystery, it eventually rewards that patience.In the beginning, you appear in Kairo with no explanation of who you are, where you are, what its or your purpose is, and no apparent indication of what you should do next, other than possibly head towards the one visible structure in the distance. Hints as to possible answers to all of those questions gradually unfold as you proceed through the three main levels of the game. Ultimately, the game never concretely answers any of those questions, but gives you enough (especially if you're determined to hunt down and unlock all of its sometimes-obscure riddles) to put together your guess, your interpretation of what you've just been through. For some this may be frustrating, not to know the absolute official canon truth of the matter, but I see it as one of the game's strengths in creating a real sense of mystery. This is not your typical berk-without-a-past-uncovers-his-past story—however much you discover, you remain without a past.The game suffers from some minor flaws in execution—the occasional video clipping problem in tight spaces, oddly getting stuck on stairs and needing to jump to continue, footstep sounds that are weirdly unsynchronized to your movement—that reflect a slight lack of polish. For me, these minor issues pale in comparison to what the game achieves artistically. It manages to create, through the grand scale of its environments, the use of colour, and its moody, atmospheric soundtrack, a feeling of being very small and alone in an intimidating, unknown world which is somehow broken and needs fixing. The puzzles involved in the fixing range from trivial to frustratingly obscure, but for the impatient there are guides and walkthroughs, and for the determined, there's a great sense of accomplishment in untangling the secret.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 20, 2013
												Kairo is an interesting sort of first-person adventure game. It's rather minimalist in that 99% of the time there is zero HUD, and there are no "use" keys. The only way to interact with the world is, much like Proteus, by just being. Standing on switches and pads, moving against things, and walking around so that objects react to your very position relative to them will solve most of the puzzles in this game.Kairo's puzzles are mostly (if not all) logical. They are, however, of the type where you will often walk into a room, have literally no idea of how the room works, leave, come back later, and solve it immediately upon walking back in. So goes Kairo. If you're ever completely and absolutely stumped, there are hints provided by the in-game menu (which unfold in a UHS-style increasingly-specific manner), though it should rarely come to that.There is a story to Kairo. I am no fan of the obtuse "insert your own ending/meaning/plot here" plots that have become so commonplace in indie games these days, and I was initially under the impression that Kairo had followed suit. But I was embarrassingly wrong. There is, underneath it all, a highly interesting story that Kairo tells. It is told over the course of the game, and the elements which make it up stare you in the face wherever you go - though you do have to put the puzzle pieces together, yourself. While I myself had noticed all of these elements and even picked up on a hint or two of where they were leading me, I completely glazed over most of it and didn't connect anything that cried out for connection.Do try not to make my mistake.There are many interesting elements at work, here. It is in the interest of receiving the best experience that you can, for you to not only solve the puzzles, but to also pay attention to the world around you, and draw as many conclusions as possible along the way.

												     From the moment the game begins to the ending sequence, Kairo's atmosphere remains powerful and unique. The world feels vast and lonely, but far from empty. The world is strange and yet eerily familiar, and the puzzles keep you involved in the goal. You can spend hours exploring the numerous rooms, each with its own atmosphere and function.     Very simple controls stop you from playing the guessing game on how to interact with things, so that the focus can be on the environment and puzzles that surround you. The music and atmospheric sounds add to the vast and lonely feeling of the world, and some elements you come across can send shivers down your spine.     If you're one for getting lost in an atmosphere, this is a game for you.

												Need a break?Welcome to the strange, yet simple and relaxing world of Kairo. It's a world filled with many ambiances, many puzzles, and many secrets.The gameplay is that simple, reduced to only movements, triggers activating by just pushing or walking passed them. Most of the puzzles also aren't difficult, with hints provided in the menu if you need some help. Though, some secrets are pretty hard to find or solve, and you might want to pass them if you don't want to spend a lot of time on them.But what makes Kairo different is the collection of ambiances and places, some people might see them like poetry, despite the lack of plot. Of course you will have a hard time enjoying this if you seek action.Overall, its a nice, short, but most importantly relaxing game.Be careful though, despite the quite simple graphics, it seems the game needs quite the resource, and you don't have many graphic options to help it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 25, 2014
												Kairo just seems like it was made for VR. The best way to describe is it is a Myst like experience where you travel through enormous rooms and areas that are large puzzles to figure out. There's no weaponry, no enemies unless you count the puzzles and you pretty much cannot die (falling off ledges just puts you back on the ledge). Each room is dominated by a simple color scheme and the architecture is large and blocky as giving the environment an ancient feel.When played on a normal monitor, the simple graphics and plain architecture might seem like a negative. However, you activate VR, put on the Rift and you realize these graphics are now a strength. Just as Valve Steam Dev Days demo showed, so long as you keep latency low and frame rate high even a simple environment will seem real. Kairo delivers on this concept in spades. The large throne rooms, invisible maze arena, hollow pyramids, giant light orb and many other breathtaking sites fill this game. The slow pace and not too mind bending puzzles mean you're seeing new areas yet have plenty of time to appreciate each one. The sounds are different for each location and all are relaxing and never seem to be over bearing or painfully loud. There are a few cases where the sudden movement of the environment surprised me, but never did I feel the need to pull out of the game. The presence is strong and even with lengthy gameplay I did not notice much if any in the way of nausea. The frame rate seems great throughout with only one room (the one with four treadmills) showing lag.Like Dear Esther, I play this game standing up and do the fake foot walk to aid in my immersion. The look is not tied to the control movement so it's easy to look around and enjoy the environment as you travel through. Its very easy to get drawn into the game and forget that you're in your room playing a game.People probably have missed that this is a VR game as it does not seem to have the "VR Support" tag in the Steam search function. I've written the author and asked if he can get that added. As I said, for only $5 you're getting several hours of a great VR experience. A perfect game for those that prefer relaxed gameplay over the horror or shooter style games currently listed with VR support.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 8, 2014
												Monoliths, glyphs, runes, buttons to step on... Kairo.For every step you take in this lonely world, you find yourself seemingly stuck and lost within yourself as well. Film grain covers your field of vision as you navigate the towers, solving a wide plethora of puzzles, from simple navigation of a simple maze to interpreting a star map just to open a door to running on treadmills, Kairo does the puzzle genre justice by infusing complex and mind-boggling puzzles towards a simplistic, minimalist world. The colours are beautiful, the gameplay is relatively solid (although I personally find the movement a little too sensitive) and this is really immersive by itself (if you play in a dark room with headphones).A drawback for me personally was that I found myself getting lost most of the time, that I was unable to have a good view of the puzzle I'm trying to solve. Like a rat in a maze, I could not see the big picture of the puzzle and I had to keep walking in circles trying to figure out what I've done, even resorting to sketching out some rooms on a piece of paper and drawing the various interactive elements on the paper so I can figure out what in the world is going on. It does interrupt the flow of the game for me sometimes and it was a little distracting to the overall feel of the game.In short, despite the few rough edges of this work of art, Kairo is really a beautiful gameset (with its fair share of really, really creepy elements and depictions here and there), really meant for the casual player to play and enjoy this surreal world, while unraveling a terrible tale that led to this place. If you're a puzzle nut and you enjoy creepy, lonely worlds, Kairo really is the place for you to be.Eurogamer has succiently highlighted the deep spine of Kairo. "Kairo is mysterious and elegant and powerfully distinct. Like Fez and Minecraft, it will work your way into your dreams if you're not careful."Play at your own risk, because Kairo does leave impressions in your mind as you play it, with the wide rooms and chilling images (when you stumble upon some seemingly "dead ends") and huge, huge glyphs.To this casual gamer's opinion:Kairo: 7.5/10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 28, 2014
												As an abstract puzzle game, Kairo is great.  The gameplay is simple yet challenging, and the built-in hint system is helpful enough to point you in the right direction when you're stuck without outright spoiling the puzzle.  However, I think the abstract design makes the story hard to follow (and leaves the player to guess); after finishing the game, I wasn't really sure what it was all about.  Still, that doesn't detract from the gameplay.  If you enjoy puzzle games and want something a little different, I would definitely recommend Kairo.Pros:- Otherworldly/alien environment.- Engaging, abstract, and unique puzzles.- Good music, which helps set a somewhat ominous and somber tone.Cons:- The story was a little *too* abstract.- Keyboard controls are not remappable, or even listed in full.  For example, the "R" key resets you to the room entrance, but I found that completely by accident.- There is no way to see your progress on collecting the hidden glyphs, except by collecting more of the glyphs.  I would like to have seen my current progress when the game is paused (such as how the map is displayed).

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 30, 2014
												It's a neat little game for what it is.  Some of the puzzles are really difficult and non-intuitive.  We're all used to games holding our hands in the beginning, training us for a little while until things progress in difficulty, but this game doesn't do that.  The puzzles aren't connected in any kind of order.  The level design is minimalistic, serving only to host the puzzles for the most part, more like a tech demo you'd see for a kickstarter project to entice fans.  The "story" is purposefully left widely open to player interpretation but it won't blow your mind in any real way.  You can tell the concept that inspired the designer to create the game is there but probably fell short of what he really wanted to do in the final product we're getting.  I could see him making a sequel and really fleshing out something from this game.The game is more artsy and vague than a flowing linear story.  It reminded me of playing Myst back in the day.  You'll find puzzles with solutions located in completely different unrelated areas.  Everything you need to solve the puzzles are located in the game for the most part, but for those of us going into this as a casual time sink just wanting to blast through it will need to look up some solutions to get all the achievements for sure.  If you get it on sale for a couple of dollars it's worth it.  It took longer than I thought it would to complete the game in its entirety, but not in an overly frustrating way.  It was a pleasant surprise.

Posted: December 29, 2014
												Kairo is a beautifully eerie shapescape that combines original style with familiar puzzle questing.  It is a simple yet aw- filled atmospheric journey that takes place in this supernatural-like world you've stumbled upon. Pros: + Increadible atmosphere.  Sometimes even daunting to look at with the great depth of field use by the dev.   + Music is more like a drone in various keys and melodies.  It's unique and quite pleasing to listen to.+ There is no linearity to it, well there is but you're free to tackle various areas at your leisure.+ Puzzles are both easy and incredibly challenging.  + Sandbox style freedom to explore the world.  It's not very large but the amount of rooms can make you forget where to go or where you've been.Cons:- There is very little if any backstory but some may say none is needed with just how odd and abstract the setting is.- Some puzzles are a little too tough because they go completely unexplained or not elluded to.Overall I would rate this game a solid 8/10.  If you're into puzzles and don't mind exploring abstract scenery with no AI interaction then this game is 100% worth it at it's price.  On sale even better.  I highly recommend it.

content:

												I bought this on sale for less than 1€, but I'd happily have paid the full price for it. it's an extremely minimalistic game, don't buy it if you absolutely need captivating plots, high-end graphics and complex gameplay or you'd be disappointed. the game is a fascinating journey through a beautifully designed surrealistic world. a really fitting ambient soundtrack adds a lot to the experience. if you've ever played Hiversaires and enjoyed it you'll really like this game as well (if you haven't go and play it). despite the 90s-like 3d graphics I was more than once amazed by the haunting and eerie scenarios and architecture of the game. along the journey you have to solve puzzles to proceed, which are decent, full of satisfying eureka-moments and quite never frustrating. it's a pretty short game tho, it took me less than 3 hours to get to the final credits, but still there were a couple of optional puzzles I didn't solve and some secrets I discovered that suggest there is something more if you find them all, so I might get back to it one day. one last note: most of the negative reviews complain about the lack of a plot and clear instructions. well I liked that instead, it's a plot device itself that adds to the unsettling feel of the game. you're thrown in without any explanation and are left with more questions than answers. picture it as a dream, no one is there to tell you where you are, what is happening and what you have to do, you just accept it and go on, and it's beautiful that way.overall solid 7.5/10, would play again.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 17, 2014
												This has been quite an experience.  I wasn't expecting nearly so much out of a little game I picked up on a whim.  According to walkthroughs, Kairo can be finished in just a half an hour if you know what you're doing, but I spent hours going through it.  The puzzles are indeed difficult at times, but what slowed me down the most was just stopping to gawk at the architecture.  It's just simple geometry and the textures are concrete, concrete and more concrete, yet somehow it's really amazing to look at.  The intense colored lighting and sheer emptiness of the massive, enigmatic spaces you get to wander through really hit with impact.  What really makes the environment pull you in though is the music.  Kairo has by far some of the best ambient background music I've ever heard.  Definitely play with good headphones if you've get 'em.  I'm officially starting my Steam category of games to go back and play again when the Oculus Rift comes out.  It's really difficult to describe the unique feeling and atmosphere of Kairo's world, but here's the best I can do:  Does anyone remember the bizarre, abstract and often borderline incoherent art-house style computer animation that occasionally showed up on TV in the late 80s and early 90s?  It's like that, but with more thinking.Gameplay consists mostly of puzzles and exploration, and both are quite rewarding.  A lot of the puzzle give that sort of Myst vibe at first glance (ie. "here are some random shapes and levers, have fun and see you in a couple hours")  but I found all of them to be fair and some were even a bit intuitive.  There were several that seemed totally abstract like they should have been frustrating to figure out, and I'm not sure if I just got lucky but the answers always clicked in my head after a bit of twiddling.  With so many puzzle types being redone to death in adventure games, it's good to see some totally new concepts that work.  My only real gripe with the puzzles are the fake ones.  Or at least apparently fake ones; I'm really not sure.  There were several rooms I faffed about in for ages before pulling up the in-game hint system to find out the room was just "here to play around with, mostly."  Mostly?  That's just lovely.  There were two places I recall getting this "hint", and they were the only two places I had to resort to using the hint system.  And then the hint is basically "this room is just here to waste your time. OR IS IT?"  Oh just♥♥♥♥♥♥off and tell me, is it or is it not a room with no purpose?  Again, just a minor gripe since I moved on when I got the aforementioned hint.There were a few other minor nitpicks I had after finishing the game, but nothing major.  There were some pretty glaring geometry glitches like hairline cracks, overlapping brushwork, misaligned textures, missing faces, and gaps that looked like they weren't supposed to be there.  Higher resolution textures could have really improved the look of a few areas too in my opinion.  Finally, while I loved the music throughout the game itself, the ending theme just didn't fit.  It's not bad or anything, but it was jarringly different from everything heard up to that point which I think detracted a bit from the final sequence.  Just my opinion.  Again, all minor things not worth too much thought.All in all, Kairo is a unique concept with some changelling puzzles and a fun bit of easter egg hunting, but it was also an unforgettable and immersive experience I won't soon forget.  It might be a bit obtuse at times for some, but if you're up for some creative problem solving in a fascinating setting, you can't do much better than this.  Hope there's more like it someday soon.

content:
Posted: June 13, 2015
												NOTE: For review with screenshots, please visit http://microfloppy.net/2015/06/14/kairo/Kairo is a puzzle exploration game. You travel the world of Kairo, trying to move forward and get to the next door… and the next… and the next.The graphics are simple – smooth and coloured walls will keep you company. It gives the game a cold and sinister feel. I felt small and lost, running around in large buildings, trying to get out.You have no inventory, no set of tools to help you out. Instead you unlock your surroundings by how and where you move and what you do. It’s a very unnerving and immersive experience.It is difficult to explain this game without saying too much. But playing Kairo, I felt like I was the last person in the world, trying desperately to find my way out of a complex I was not meant to be in. If you like first-person explorations games, you should play this one.7/10

												I actually had no idea what I was getting into when I got this game, but I am so glad I did. 												Kairo is actually one of the better puzzle games that I've played, blending atmosphere with mystery and tossing a few challenging puzzles in between. Many of the early puzzles are not particularly challenging, mostly consisting of pushing a chair or something, but they do gradually get more challenging. Overall, I enjoyed Kairo immensely. I would recommend this to anybody who likes a good puzzle and a good atmosphere (basically, if you liked Portal, you will probably like this too). Totally worth it for the 2 bucks I paid for it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 30, 2014
												It's a neat little game for what it is.  Some of the puzzles are really difficult and non-intuitive.  We're all used to games holding our hands in the beginning, training us for a little while until things progress in difficulty, but this game doesn't do that.  The puzzles aren't connected in any kind of order.  The level design is minimalistic, serving only to host the puzzles for the most part, more like a tech demo you'd see for a kickstarter project to entice fans.  The "story" is purposefully left widely open to player interpretation but it won't blow your mind in any real way.  You can tell the concept that inspired the designer to create the game is there but probably fell short of what he really wanted to do in the final product we're getting.  I could see him making a sequel and really fleshing out something from this game.The game is more artsy and vague than a flowing linear story.  It reminded me of playing Myst back in the day.  You'll find puzzles with solutions located in completely different unrelated areas.  Everything you need to solve the puzzles are located in the game for the most part, but for those of us going into this as a casual time sink just wanting to blast through it will need to look up some solutions to get all the achievements for sure.  If you get it on sale for a couple of dollars it's worth it.  It took longer than I thought it would to complete the game in its entirety, but not in an overly frustrating way.  It was a pleasant surprise.

												If you're a myst fan then this will be right up your alley. Stepping out into to the monolithic environments of Kairo is akin to stepping out onto that dock in myst for the first time. While basically a walking simulator, there where times that I was simply awestruck by the towering structures and deep shadows the dominate its barren landscape. Kairo is also a very decent puzzler, requiring you to pay close attencion to your surroundings in order to peice everything together. 												I love love love this game. Although this game has a vague story as well as (mostly) strictly geometrical graphics, Kairo use both to its advantage. Despite the simple shapes that Kairo is constructed of, the creator really did a good job with making the environments interesting. A really strong point in Kairo is the environment coupled with the use of sound. I really love the strangeness that the sound adds to the atmosphere. There are several structures in Kairo that emit static, random arrays of numbers, and other strange noises. Anyway. Yes, I recomend the game. if you like casual exploration and trippy areas to explore, you'll like it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 22, 2015
												Kairo is a slow-paced puzzle game in a similar vein to Myst, if Myst didn't have all the annoying pixel-hunting and weren't a point and click game. Its atmosphere is surreal, strange, and overwhelmingly lonesome. That's the big word I think I'd use to describe this game - lonesome, and that lonesomeness becomes more and more eerie the further you go into the game. You are the only living thing in Kairo - everything else is a hollow, dead fascimile, with archetecture eerily reminiscent of human construction and yet alien enough you might think you woke up in R'lyeh. The world of Kairo is a small world that feels massive, alien, and completely dead... and I love it to pieces and back.Wandering through the surreal and beautifully eerie world of Kairo is very relaxing, the puzzles are very intuitive and can easily be solved with a little thought, and the simple design really makes it feel like you're stranded. And yet, solving the puzzles is so satisfying, satisfying in that "I'm a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ed genius!" sort of way. The range of feelings you get from Kairo goes from triumph, curiosity, and awe to fright, paranoia, and hopelessness - and what is art if not something that makes you feel deeply? Anyone who claims video games aren't art has never played this, and that's a damn shame. Did I mention that the music and the game's design is just so surrealistically gorgeous?Seriously, BUY THIS GAME. It's maybe $5 for a wonderful little piece of surrealistic artwork that recaptures the eerie loneliness and thirst for adventure that Myst did so many years ago in 1992. Kairo is a gem of an indie puzzle game, and anyone who is a fan of surreal artwork, puzzle games, and games where you chill and wander for a bit will love this. You really do owe it to yourself to play it at least once. Who knows? It may become one of your favorite games, just like it has for me.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 25, 2015
												If you're looking for a deep, challenging puzzle game with an ambiguous and surreal atmosphere, then have another go at using that search box because you seem to have mispelled Antichamber. I wouldn't mention it, except you can't seem to go 5 minutes of reading about this game without it being compared to Antichamber (indeed, this comparison is what brought me to the game in the first place), and I simply can't see why. Kairo is nothing like Antichamber, and if you're expecting it to be then you're about to be sorely disappointed. This is not to say that I didn't like Kairo, as you can presumably tell from the fact that this review is a recommendation. It's just that my initial view of it was tainted because I was constantly trying to compare it to Antichamber, and in that comparison it, like most games, falls very far short.First, the bad. The "puzzles"  are probably the main thing here. Barring a few rather interesting ones, they can be solved with minimal effort as soon as you work out what each element of the environment actually is. The main problem, I feel is the lack of a central mechanic. With no way to interract with the environment besides standing on things, puzzle design is extremely limited. In the game's defense, it uses this limited capacity well and rarely repeates itself, but nonetheless you will likely find much of the game unchallenging. Furthermore, the much-touted atmosphere is... eh. It's not bad, but it tries too hard to be creepy, which simply doesn't work with the gameplay. There are a few very effective moments, but overall you'll probably find you just don't notice it.However, the game just about makes up for these shortcomings with its stronger points. The environment design is excellent, using a rather minimalist block-based design for buildings which contrasts effectively with the more detailed decoration and interactable objects. Along with providing some spectacular views, this helps greatly with distinguishing puzzle piece from environment and the intuitive level design means you'll have little difficulty with finding your way around. Finally, the ending. Oh the ending. I strongly recommend playing through once to get the normal ending, then finding a guide online and playing through again for the hidden one. It won't have as much of an impact if you didn't play through once blind, but I honestly can't think of a way it could have ended better. Utterly unexpected yet actually carefully foreshadowed, it ties the game together and makes you look at the product as a whole from a completely different angle. Overall, I recommend Kairo, but only just. It makes up for its shortcomings in a number of ways, and it's certainly fairly unique. If you're looking for a challenge (or, like me, something Antichamber-esque), you won't find it. However, if you're looking for an unusual experience that effectively kills a few hours, you could do a lot worse. For only £4, I'd say it's worth the money.

Puzzles were nice, except for a few, which were really stupidly hard. The game is not that long at all, so these few dark spots really put a dent in the overall experience.I almost gave this a thumbs down, but at the end of the day, it did hold my attention, and I did say twice in this review that I enjoyed it, so it gets a thumbs up from me. But just barely.
