content:
Posted: September 18, 2015
												Okay, let's get one thing out of the way first: this game does not look good. The trailer above kinda oversells the graphics — they're not minimalistic, they're cheap.That being said, everything else about Kairo is great.Distant cousin of Myst, this game is comprised mostly of puzzles. And there is a compelling diversity in these: some are very easy, some are very difficult; some totally straightforward, some mind-bendingly abstract; and of course everything in between. This makes the progression always enticing and never boring. The level design is very cool despite the poor graphics and each level has its own unique feel, the whole game being very "atmospheric". This is brilliantly reinforced by the marvelous sound design, with a really, really awesome music that transported me from puzzle to puzzle in a dream-like state.Thanks to all these strenghts, Kairo manages to be at the same time fun and relaxing. It is a journey, really, in a land full of mysteries and secrets, where lots of questions are raised and no explanations given — you make your own conclusions from the scarce clues given along the path.I have no idea how to grade it out of ten, but I am positive that I'd recommend it in a heartbeat to pretty much anyone. The only major flaw that I would point out is the absence of V-Sync which allows some MASSIVE tearing to occur. And the Field of View is rendered in layers, which looks kinda awful. But other than that, well... What's not to like? You like puzzles? Get it. Like "moody" games? It's a good one. Like quality OSTs? This one's perfect. You like Myst? Don't hesitate! There even is a skeleton hidden somewhere. Spooky!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 5, 2015
												IMPORTANT: When you hit the normal ending, wait for the credits to play out. They're not long.Pros:- Puzzles become interesting when you have no "hand" or "activate" controls. By limiting the player to mere movement controls, old puzzles feel fresh, and there's an extra sense of accomplishment with even fairly simple puzzles.- The environment's minimalist polygon theme manages, surprisingly, to stay varied, interesting, and even evokative throughout the game, contributing to the theme of "strange and yet familiar" that pervades.- Difficulty to normal end is low, difficulty to secret end is high.- No penalty for exploration, experimentation, or taking your time.- Overall, definitely enjoyable.Cons:- The "story" aspect is a little too vague. You paid $5, folks, this ain't Myst or Portal. While there are enough "clues" that a player can vaguely put together a plot (and considerably more blatant clues as rewards for solving secret puzzles), there's plenty that's just left to imagination.- The mechanic that resets you to a safe ledge can glitch considerably, leaving you in a fall-to-your-death loop, though this can be solved by exiting the game and reloading.- One of the final secret puzzles is actually impossible to solve on your own. Your game will have 1/5 of the solution, and which fifth is chosen at random. So you're either going to need lots of friends, or cheat and look at a walkthrough.Final Note: Don't take my playtime as a good guide to the runthrough time of this game. I got irritated and consulted a walkthrough for two of the secret puzzles and half the rune locations.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 29, 2015
												I got this game for $1. And I'm glad I scooped it up! A great puzzle/exploration game with enigmas abound.GAMEPLAY: Consists of walking, jumping, and looking around. It's straightforward exploration with minor platforming. Puzzles round out the play, which you complete by stepping on platforms and bumping into objects to trigger them.PUZZLES: They're pretty intuitive for the most part, but there were a few I had to consult the helpfully provided "hints" option for (one in particular was hair rippingly frustrating because I'm terrible at math). Be prepared to comb areas carefully for clues, and draw out some diagrams here and there. It's quite satisfying to solve these puzzles, as they're fairly challenging, and it's made clear when you have activated a piece of machinery or opened a pathway by way of flashing lights, thunderous tumults, or loud gong strikes. It all amounts to a feeling of progress and getting one step closer to solving the mystery.VISUALS: Very minimalistic. Oftentimes, you wander through barren corridors or empty voids, with sparsely a decoration to look at. What there is to look at, though, serves to deepen the mystery. It feels like everything being presented - from images of Earth to the DNA double helix - has some type of underlying meaning. Otherwise, lighting and colouring is used to differentiate rooms, creating a very surreal effect. There's also some use of moving objects - floating, spinning globes, for example - that add some variance. In all, it's simplistic, but only where it needs to be.AUDIO: The highlight of the game for me. Again, simplicity is the standard here - a haunting, ambient soundtrack makes the place feel mysterious, dangerous, and cozy all at once. It's a strange effect, but it keeps the player guessing as to what, exactly, these structures are. As mentioned before, loud, sudden bells and gongs are used to indicate that the player has completed a puzzle, which is pretty satisfying. Radio static in certain locations and chimes during object interaction round out the auditory experience. Like the graphics, it feels like the sounds of the game highlight what's important.STORY: Ostensibly, there isn't much of one. There is virtually no dialogue or cutscenes, and there are no NPCs present. Only environmental clues, mainly through recurring motifs, give rise to some semblance of a plot. I enjoyed wondering what Kairo could be about, and reading theories about it afterward.Overall, a great experience, which is even nicer considering I got this game for $1. It reminded me a lot of Myst (and Penumbra, somehow). There are mysteries to be unravelled for those willing to search for them.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 14, 2015
												Minimalist, abstract, and esoteric. I picked up a copy of Kairo because it was on sale and it looked interesting and played it through to completion (with the help of a guide to point me in the direction of my objectives, I admit. They're not that obvious some of the time).Kairo manages to combine my two least favorite things in a game: slippery controls and almost required sprinting. In-game you can hear your footsteps so I know my feet weren't covered in oil... but it certainly felt like it. Many of the areas are expansive, which is cool, but if you want to try to complete the game the way I did you will need to backtrack through areas you've already visited. At times like these I found myself holding down the sprint key just to get through these areas as fast as possible. After about an hour of this, my left hand is pretty sore.On the positive side the environments were cool and my favorite puzzle mechanic- the block puzzles where you have to stand in a certain position in the room to solve them- didn't feel like it was used often enough. I think there's enough in that idea alone to make an entire game out of, should the developer give it a try.That said I cannot, in good faith, recommend Kairo. Not at full price, anyway. Five bucks for a ~3 hour game that's uncomfortable to play during the second half isn't a great deal by any stretch of the imagination.

content:
Posted: November 28, 2014
												As an abstract puzzle game, Kairo is great.  The gameplay is simple yet challenging, and the built-in hint system is helpful enough to point you in the right direction when you're stuck without outright spoiling the puzzle.  However, I think the abstract design makes the story hard to follow (and leaves the player to guess); after finishing the game, I wasn't really sure what it was all about.  Still, that doesn't detract from the gameplay.  If you enjoy puzzle games and want something a little different, I would definitely recommend Kairo.Pros:- Otherworldly/alien environment.- Engaging, abstract, and unique puzzles.- Good music, which helps set a somewhat ominous and somber tone.Cons:- The story was a little *too* abstract.- Keyboard controls are not remappable, or even listed in full.  For example, the "R" key resets you to the room entrance, but I found that completely by accident.- There is no way to see your progress on collecting the hidden glyphs, except by collecting more of the glyphs.  I would like to have seen my current progress when the game is paused (such as how the map is displayed).

												If you're a myst fan then this will be right up your alley. Stepping out into to the monolithic environments of Kairo is akin to stepping out onto that dock in myst for the first time. Kairo is able to conjur up an atmosphere of loneliness and mystery that really sticks with you the whole game. While basically a walking simulator, there where times that I was simply awestruck by the towering structures and deep shadows the dominate its barren landscape. Aparrently it has oculus support as well, which put this first on the list of things i'm going to play when I finally have the funds to join the VR club. Kairo is also a very decent puzzler, requiring you to pay close attencion to your surroundings in order to peice everything together. While a few of the puzzles can get rather abstract, I never found myself stuck becuase of a handy hint system you can use to cheat if ever need be. For the price you can get it at, this game delivers a unique experience that you won't find anywhere else. I'd highly recommend it to anyone who enjoys atmosphere and immersion, and doesn't mind being stumped by a puzzle from time to time.

content:
Posted: May 25, 2014
												Kairo is an interesting, if ultimately slight, atmospheric puzzle game.  The artwork is all rectangles and circles and simple geometric shapes.  The music exists simply to generate atmosphere.  There is no "plot," but rather a series of puzzles that are to be completed simply because they exist.  The puzzles are generally fairly easy, although there are no real instructions and most of the puzzles require you to use your surroundings to figure out what to do.  In addition the "secret" puzzles are a pretty big step up in difficulty and will likely resort to the user having to consult a guide.All of that said, the game succeeds with what it's trying to do.  The atmosphere is engrossing and engaging and the game is neither too easy or too difficult.  It's really a shame it was only 3-4 hours long, 'cause I think it could have been twice as long and not worn out its welcome.Rating: 8/10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 13, 2014
												This game didn't take too long to finish, but somehow I managed to wait for months in between sessions and forget what was going on.  So I would NOT do that, were I to live life a second time.This game has a few REALLY killer puzzles, and I am a snob about puzzles, so that is saying something.  I think the number one thing that made this game work is it's utter abstractness.  Many of the best puzzles were fairly simple tasks, but understanding how the mechanisms worked was a challending and engaging task, simply because of the lack of context.One of the most interesting and unique things about this game is the cool control scheme in which the position where you are standing affects the state of the world.  This is used in a variety of ways, and it somehow manages to make very simple puzzles a lot more engaging.On the down side, this game was definitely lacking in polish.  Movement was slightly glitchy - especially going up stairs and jumping off walls (which I'm not sure you were supposed to be able to do at all).  There were often cheap looking cracks between blocks that didn't quite touch.  Some icons looked like poorly clipped .pngs.  Just a little rough around the edges.Also the "story" kept getting devastatingly interesting, and then leaving you hanging.  Ending was super weird (secret ending was even weirder.  But no, I didn't get it, I watched it on youtube :P)

content:
Posted: September 17, 2014
												There are two ways to approach Kairo. The first is to view it as a meditative experience in an open world with many soothing  environments and lots of exploration. The second view is to see it as a string of puzzles that need to be solved to complete and beat the game.You'll enjoy it either way you view it. If you decide to explore, you will see many different areas, and come to love the fact that you can hide away in the world of Kairo and relax after a long day. Walk around in the Park, look at the alien structures, and relax to the calm sounds of water rushing, or birds chirping.And if you take it as a string of puzzles, you will be challenged with a system with no interaction button, with clues to guide you when you are lost. You will push things, pull things, and eventually get the machines that govern the world of Kairo running.And be treated to a delightful and uplifting ending.

Turning the mouse option sensitiving to about 10%2. Turning Grain off3. Turning the Motion Smoother off

content:
Posted: December 29, 2014
												Kairo is a beautifully eerie shapescape that combines original style with familiar puzzle questing.  It is a simple yet aw- filled atmospheric journey that takes place in this supernatural-like world you've stumbled upon. Pros: + Increadible atmosphere.  Sometimes even daunting to look at with the great depth of field use by the dev.   + Music is more like a drone in various keys and melodies.  It's unique and quite pleasing to listen to.+ There is no linearity to it, well there is but you're free to tackle various areas at your leisure.+ Puzzles are both easy and incredibly challenging.  + Sandbox style freedom to explore the world.  It's not very large but the amount of rooms can make you forget where to go or where you've been.Cons:- There is very little if any backstory but some may say none is needed with just how odd and abstract the setting is.- Some puzzles are a little too tough because they go completely unexplained or not elluded to.Overall I would rate this game a solid 8/10.  If you're into puzzles and don't mind exploring abstract scenery with no AI interaction then this game is 100% worth it at it's price.  On sale even better.  I highly recommend it.

												An extremely underrated game -- period. This game boasts a power to enthrall and captivate you, without needing an actual story the game almost speaks to you on a mystical level. The puzzles aren't easy but not too difficult, and there are very creative ideas put into it. The game also has intresting architecture and mysterious entities. It is a game that pulls you out of reality and puts you into this weird, but neat sublime world. I would say that this game is kinda like a more linear based LSD: Dream Simulator for the PS1 with puzzles. They both provoke unique mystery in an intresting and meaningful way. Posted: August 15, 2013
												Kairo is a great little game with really nice logic puzzles that aren't too difficult but requires some thinking. The game hints at a story but it's very vague and it could just as well have no story. The thing I really loved about Kairo was the atmosphere it created, it made me feel very isolated and small because the levels were usually very big and empty and it had a very minimalist environment. The atmosphere got creepy at times as things such as static on the screen would flare up and number station recordings would play as you got closer to certain areas. The game always had me questioning things, because sometimes strange objects or symbols would be around and it would make me want to know why they were there or what they meant. I also liked the ambient music as that too helped with the atmosphere and it fits right into the game.

content:
Posted: June 30, 2014
												It's a neat little game for what it is.  Some of the puzzles are really difficult and non-intuitive.  We're all used to games holding our hands in the beginning, training us for a little while until things progress in difficulty, but this game doesn't do that.  The puzzles aren't connected in any kind of order.  The level design is minimalistic, serving only to host the puzzles for the most part, more like a tech demo you'd see for a kickstarter project to entice fans.  The "story" is purposefully left widely open to player interpretation but it won't blow your mind in any real way.  You can tell the concept that inspired the designer to create the game is there but probably fell short of what he really wanted to do in the final product we're getting.  I could see him making a sequel and really fleshing out something from this game.The game is more artsy and vague than a flowing linear story.  It reminded me of playing Myst back in the day.  You'll find puzzles with solutions located in completely different unrelated areas.  Everything you need to solve the puzzles are located in the game for the most part, but for those of us going into this as a casual time sink just wanting to blast through it will need to look up some solutions to get all the achievements for sure.  If you get it on sale for a couple of dollars it's worth it.  It took longer than I thought it would to complete the game in its entirety, but not in an overly frustrating way.  It was a pleasant surprise.

Posted: June 25, 2014
												At first I thought this was another weird artsy fartsy game, but man, was I proved wrong. It's a semi-complex first person puzzle game that boasts a stylish yet minimalistic design that keeps you intrigued. Albeit, at times, the graphics can look a bit bland or bad, I overlook the aforementioned flaws because of how interesting the game is. A few of the puzzles actually require a bit of thinking as opposed to just flat out putting pieces wherever you feel they go. Luckily, there is a hint option in the pause screen. I had been eyeing this game for a while and saw it go on sale a couple of days ago. I highly recommend this game if you are intrigued by visual puzzles.

												I got about 7 hours out of this game, and for the price I got it at ($0.99 while on sale), I would have to say that it is definitely one of the more enjoyable puzzle games I've played recently. It manages to do a lot of things without using too much, and it does it quite well. I can definitely recommend this game to anyone looking to pick it up.That being said, be warned in advance, this game is not easy. Some of the puzzles are rather difficult to figure out, and a few even require back tracking at a much later date. You will also probably need a guide if you intend to 100% this game. My advice, is try to do your first run as bare bones as possible, consulting the guide as little as possible, just to experience the game. Then, you can speed run through it the second time grabbing all the things you missed your first run through.

Posted: January 17, 2015
												Kairo is beautiful, plain and simple. It is an adventure from the begining. Not because of the adrenaline injections most games rely on and many gamers are addicted to. Everything is so carefully placed as to invoke a sense of haunting and ancient beauty. The game reminds me of a ghost story. Your character is in search of a ghost (let's say the ghost of his wife.) His search has led him to the ancient temple where all spirits reside. He must return life to all of the spirits in the temple to find his wife. Bad fanfiction aside, this game is pure genius and I want all of my friends to play it.

content:
Posted: January 17, 2015
												This is a pretty interesting game. Though oftentimes it suffers from the same problem as similar indie titles. It'll forget it's an abstract first person puzzle game and become Sculpture Garden Simulator 2015. Yes game, when walk through your rooms I appreciate your post-modernist, minimalist design that recalls Egyptian, Chinese and Classical art. But when you place these puzzle-less rooms in between the puzzles, you're really hurting the pacing. Though for $0.74 (as of this writing) , I definitely recommend picking it up. The puzzles are just challenging enough and if you have trouble the game has a pretty generous hint system.

content:
Posted: January 1, 2015
												A very atmospheric game both visually and audibly, making for a pleasurable journey to the end. Although puzzle based the puzzles are not so hard (or just guesswork based) as to be annoying. With a little thought all but a couple of the puzzles can be solved in reasonable amount of time (and those that can't belong to the 'achievements' section, so they do not hinder you from completing the game).   I loved the pace of this game, the feeling of being somewhere that matters, perhaps because the game hints through its imagery that the place is somehow significant and that you aren't just wandering around without meaning. There was no rush, no one chasing and it was easy to get from point to point without a lot of walking.  Kairo is a relaxing game to play. Enjoyable too.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 22, 2014
												If you want a tl;dr of my review, it's basically just "If you like atmospheric exploration games, buy it".My ACTUAL review is:Kairo is an interesting game to say the least, I feel like there was an actual vision behind the developer and for the most part I think his vision came through, however the limited resources he had are fatally apparent. The film grain effect is just a static overlay that feels more distracting than stylistic, and while early areas of the game are very visually engaging and seem like they have a plan and purpose behind their layout, later areas just feel slapped together, using almost random geometric shapes and often just feel like the design had little to no thought at all. A fair amount of rooms have a purposefully grand scale, which is usually unnessicary considering you have to run back and forth in them to solve a puzzle. Of course this might be a purposeful choice to evoke a specific emotion from that level, I just felt pulled out of the experience. Now obviously I can't review a game without discussing how it plays and the mechanics, which also sadly fall flat. The game only gives you three commands, the ability to look, jump, and sprint. Nothing else. This is sometimes problematic to solving puzzles as you need to physically touch certain objects in order to "activate" them. While feeling awkward by itself, the player has a sort of floaty momentum to them that is accentuated by the fact you need to ram into objects to solve puzzles, which are also obtuse. There are different symbols used to differentiate switches, but the logic behind them often changes. Sometimes they're supposed to be literal, as in you have to activate the exact sime switch, but sometimes they're representations of numbers, which is confusing when the rest of the game had been using a literal interpretation. Luckily there is a hint system built in, which solves most of my gripes with the presentation not being very clear.All in all, I feel like this game needs a lot of polish, but is still worth the price, especially if it's on sale.

content:
Posted: January 18, 2016
												I liked it. The game has a nice surreal ambiance and sorta eerie music. You walk through majestic and mysterious places solving puzzles, some simple, some that might need a google search. Only once did I actually need a google search to help me solve a puzzle (turns out i was right about how to solve it, was just applying it incorrectly). Solving every secret and puzzle, especially those not required to beat the game, will definitely take an internet search to finish.Gameplay only requires moving and the rare jump and nothing else. There are no other requirements, all puzzles are solved with simply walking, and buttons/interactive objects are used simply by walking up to/on them. The simplicity of both gameplay and the story telling is not for everyone, but I personally loved the game.I would recommend this game for people who enjoying exploring and doing unrequired things in games and also enjoy puzzles and deep thinking. If you prefer very linear and directed gameplay or don't enjoy going outside of the main story to explore, you probably will dislike the game.

												Kairo is a slightly flawed gem of a first-person walking and exploration game. It requires a bit of investment to stay interested in the beginning, but if you're into discovery and piecing together parts of a mystery, it eventually rewards that patience.In the beginning, you appear in Kairo with no explanation of who you are, where you are, what its or your purpose is, and no apparent indication of what you should do next, other than possibly head towards the one visible structure in the distance. Hints as to possible answers to all of those questions gradually unfold as you proceed through the three main levels of the game. Ultimately, the game never concretely answers any of those questions, but gives you enough (especially if you're determined to hunt down and unlock all of its sometimes-obscure riddles) to put together your guess, your interpretation of what you've just been through. For some this may be frustrating, not to know the absolute official canon truth of the matter, but I see it as one of the game's strengths in creating a real sense of mystery. This is not your typical berk-without-a-past-uncovers-his-past story—however much you discover, you remain without a past.The game suffers from some minor flaws in execution—the occasional video clipping problem in tight spaces, oddly getting stuck on stairs and needing to jump to continue, footstep sounds that are weirdly unsynchronized to your movement—that reflect a slight lack of polish. For me, these minor issues pale in comparison to what the game achieves artistically. It manages to create, through the grand scale of its environments, the use of colour, and its moody, atmospheric soundtrack, a feeling of being very small and alone in an intimidating, unknown world which is somehow broken and needs fixing. The puzzles involved in the fixing range from trivial to frustratingly obscure, but for the impatient there are guides and walkthroughs, and for the determined, there's a great sense of accomplishment in untangling the secret.

												A friend of mine showed me this game a while back, he bought it for me and I'm glad he did. I really enjoyed the puzzles and how it looked, especially the grain filter, that gave it a really interesting feel. The game is not horror at all, though it can be a bit spooky due to the environment and the sounds, but thats what I loved about it. The game also had a Myst feel to it, if anyone reading this actually knows what that game is. Sure this game may seem strange at first, but give it a try, you might actually like it! Definitely worth the price.

content:
Posted: August 22, 2015
												Kairo is a slow-paced puzzle game in a similar vein to Myst, if Myst didn't have all the annoying pixel-hunting and weren't a point and click game. Its atmosphere is surreal, strange, and overwhelmingly lonesome. That's the big word I think I'd use to describe this game - lonesome, and that lonesomeness becomes more and more eerie the further you go into the game. You are the only living thing in Kairo - everything else is a hollow, dead fascimile, with archetecture eerily reminiscent of human construction and yet alien enough you might think you woke up in R'lyeh. The world of Kairo is a small world that feels massive, alien, and completely dead... and I love it to pieces and back.Wandering through the surreal and beautifully eerie world of Kairo is very relaxing, the puzzles are very intuitive and can easily be solved with a little thought, and the simple design really makes it feel like you're stranded. And yet, solving the puzzles is so satisfying, satisfying in that "I'm a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ed genius!" sort of way. The range of feelings you get from Kairo goes from triumph, curiosity, and awe to fright, paranoia, and hopelessness - and what is art if not something that makes you feel deeply? Anyone who claims video games aren't art has never played this, and that's a damn shame. Did I mention that the music and the game's design is just so surrealistically gorgeous?Seriously, BUY THIS GAME. It's maybe $5 for a wonderful little piece of surrealistic artwork that recaptures the eerie loneliness and thirst for adventure that Myst did so many years ago in 1992. Kairo is a gem of an indie puzzle game, and anyone who is a fan of surreal artwork, puzzle games, and games where you chill and wander for a bit will love this. You really do owe it to yourself to play it at least once. Who knows? It may become one of your favorite games, just like it has for me.

content:
Posted: September 6, 2015
												I quite enjoyed this game. The atmosphere was great, and it looked really cool. However, some of the puzzles were a bit -too- abstract, and for some reason touching a wall caused my framerate to drop dramatically. This got annoying in some areas, espeically being that the controls in this game aren't very tight, even with the settings tweaked. Some areas a a bit bigger than they need to be, so there's a lot of walking to do. Thank goodness there's a sprint button, but it doesn't change your speed that much. This game has very little replay value, unless you're one of those people who want to painstakingly go through every nook and cranny to find these tiny symbols tucked in corners of the levels.I think the game was trying to tell me a story, but I didn't get any sort of feeling of resolution at the end, unless I am supposed to find all those little symbols. That sounds absolutely miserable though. That would be like playing a 3d eye spy game. I have better things to do with my life.Overall, I enjoyed the game. Puzzles were nice, except for a few, which were really stupidly hard. The game is not that long at all, so these few dark spots really put a dent in the overall experience.I almost gave this a thumbs down, but at the end of the day, it did hold my attention, and I did say twice in this review that I enjoyed it, so it gets a thumbs up from me. But just barely.

content:
Posted: April 6
												Even if the bland and desolate landscapes compliment the theme of the game, at some points it was taken too far and made some parts quite a chore. The storyline puzzles were of good difficulty, but for the hidden puzzles I had to consult a guide. Perhaps they would've been doable with careful note taking. The runes were of OK difficulty, although I only realized they existed at the end of the first area.Ran smoothly on my 2955U (1.4 GHz dualcore) 2GB RAM machine using the PS3 SIXAXIS controller via xboxdrv. Controls were decent enough, although the character had quite a bit of momentum. In my opinion the run could've been used by default while holding a button had made the character walk.TL;DR: A decent game if you like some FPS adventuring and puzzle solving. Bought at a discount, but even the asking price isn't bad for what the game offers.

Posted: December 31, 2016
												I enjoyed kairo. It was a really cool puzzle game, and although it was really short, I was satisfied with it. The abstract minimalist environments and the great music really added to the atmosphere of the game. That being said, the normal ending was pretty bad, but I don't think that's reason enough for a negative review. You should buy this game if you like stylish games like journey or abzu, but for people who like puzzle solving games, the puzzles in this one are a bit easy and tedious at times.

content:
Posted: April 7
												It's like Dark Souls if you took out the RPG stuff and replaced it with puzzles. Explore some sort of ruins, fix some machines and hope for the best, and hopefully figure out what's going on.You get what you pay for, though, and this really is only worth about a tenth of a AAA title at best. There are similarly priced games that are more bang for your bulk, but there's something to be said for lighter fare. It's like getting a salad instead of a burger. Buy at your own discretion, but it would make a good thing to show someone not very into gaming, like a kid or a parent.

												My wife and I had a blast playing this game! We loved the creativity and open-world style of it. It reminded me a lot of the spirit of Myst and Riven from my childhood. No hand-holding! The puzzles were challenging, and we got stuck on several. After enough wandering, though, we could always figure it out -- well, almost always.

content:
Posted: April 26
												Kairo pales drastically in comparison to critically acclaimed success, Myst: a game of similar presentation and design caliber, created with a modest budget for its time, and which made a far greater impact on the gaming world. Kairo takes any and all reason that could (and frankly should) be percieved within a puzzle game, wipes its proverbial posterior with it, and readily hands it back to you with a childish snigger. What facets of Kairo that would seem to lead towards some sort of explanation is eerily creepy and unsatisfactory because it doesn't explain a single thing. I found it a disappointment and a borderline insult to the puzzle game genre.
